problem.tex: Prove that a harmonic function $u$ on $\Omega$ satisfies the mean value property, which we rename the circle mean value property. Prove also that $u$ satisfies the ball mean value property that for all $a\in\Omega$ and all $r>0$ small enough that $\overline{B_r(a)}\subset\Omega$ \[u(a)=\frac{1}{\pi r^2}\iint_{B_r(a)}u(x+iy)dxdy.\]

solution.tex: By choice of $a,r$ there is a simply connected open subset of $\Omega$ which contains $\overline{B_r(a)}$. Take a harmonic conjugate $v$ on this neighborhood to obtain the holomorphic function $f=u+iv$. Recall Cauchy's integral formula, \[f(a)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|z-a|=r}\frac{f(z)}{z-a}dz.\] Restating with $u$ and $v$ gives \[u(a)+iv(a)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{u(a+re^{it})+iv(a+re^{it})}{re^{it}}ire^{it}dt=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}u(a+re^{it})+iv(a+re^{it})dt.\] The real part of the above equation is the circle mean value property. Let $0<s<r$. Because $u$ satisfies the circle mean value property, \[u(a)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_0^{2\pi}u(a+se^{i\theta})d\theta.\] Scale both sides by $s$. \[2\pi su(a)=\int_0^{2\pi}u(a+se^{i\theta})sd\theta.\] Integrate both sides with respect to $s$ from $0$ to $r$. \[\pi r^2u(a)=\int_0^r\int_0^{2\pi}u(a+se^{i\theta})sd\theta ds=\iint_{B_r(a)}u(x+iy)dxdy.\]
